newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Miners strike at Portuguese copper mine.
newsitem.headline: Miners strike at Portuguese copper mine.

text.p: Several hundred miners at Portugal's Neves Corvo copper mine, Europe's largest, began an indefinite strike on Monday over working hours, company and labour officials said.
A spokesman for Somincor, the state-owned company that operates the mine, said that output was expected to drop to around 20 percent of usual production immediately as a result of the action.

But according to radio reports, pickets of striking workers were blocking access to the mine near Beja, some 250 km (156 miles) south-east of Lisbon, raising the question of whether any work would be possible.
The mine produced 107,000 tonnes of copper in 1996, down from 129,700 the year before. It also produces small quantities of tin.

Neves Corvo employs some 500 miners who are angry at the company's plans to introduce seven-day shifts. The company says falling copper yields mean more intensive working of the mine is necessary to ensure that it can compete with other international producers.

Output at the mine has fallen steadily from nearly 160,000 tonnes in 1990 as yields have declined from 10.8 percent to 6.3 percent in 1996, the company said in a statement. "In the present circumstances, continuous working of the mine has become absolutely indispensable," it said.
